user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_FileOpen_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_FileOpen_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const char *local_path, int32 flags, int32 access_mode)
{
    int                             os_perm;
    int                             os_mode;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    /*
    ** Check for a valid access mode
    ** For creating a file, OS_READ_ONLY does not make sense
    */
    switch (access_mode)
    {
        case OS_WRITE_ONLY:
            os_perm = O_WRONLY;
            break;
        case OS_READ_ONLY:
            os_perm = O_RDONLY;
            break;
        case OS_READ_WRITE:
            os_perm = O_RDWR;
            break;
        default:
            return OS_ERROR;
    }

    if (flags & OS_FILE_FLAG_CREATE)
    {
        os_perm |= O_CREAT;
    }
    if (flags & OS_FILE_FLAG_TRUNCATE)
    {
        os_perm |= O_TRUNC;
    }

    os_perm |= OS_IMPL_REGULAR_FILE_FLAGS;

    os_mode = S_IRUSR | S_IWUSR | S_IRGRP | S_IWGRP | S_IROTH | S_IWOTH;

    impl->fd = open(local_path, os_perm, os_mode);

    if (impl->fd < 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("open(%s): %s\n", local_path, strerror(errno));
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    /*
     * If the flags included O_NONBLOCK, then
     * enable the "select" call on this handle.
     */
    impl->selectable = ((os_perm & O_NONBLOCK) != 0);

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_FileOpen_Impl:
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
...
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
int32 OS_OpenCreate(osal_id_t *filedes, const char *path, int32 flags, int32 access_mode)
{
    int32                        return_code;
    char                         local_path[OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN];
    OS_object_token_t            token;
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(filedes);

    /* Initialize file descriptor */
    *filedes = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;

    /*
    ** Check for a valid access mode
    */
    if (access_mode != OS_WRITE_ONLY && access_mode != OS_READ_ONLY && access_mode != OS_READ_WRITE)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    /*
     * Translate the path
     */
    return_code = OS_TranslatePath(path, (char *)local_path);

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /* Note - the common ObjectIdAllocate routine will lock the object type and leave it locked. */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, NULL, &token);
        if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
        {
            stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, token);

            /* Reset the table entry and save the name */
            OS_OBJECT_INIT(token, stream, stream_name, path);

            /* Now call the OS-specific implementation.  */
            return_code = OS_FileOpen_Impl(&token, local_path, flags, access_mode);

            /* Check result, finalize record, and unlock global table. */
            return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew(return_code, &token, filedes);
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_WRITE_ONLY 1
...
#define OS_READ_ONLY 0
...
#define OS_READ_WRITE 2
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
extern const int OS_IMPL_REGULAR_FILE_FLAGS
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I have reported fragments that could indicate unreachable code or overlapping defensive checks that should be investigated for Rule 2.1: (1) the switch default in OS_FileOpen_Impl and (2) the access_mode validation in OS_OpenCreate are directly related — if OS_FileOpen_Impl is only ever called from OS_OpenCreate, the switch default may be unreachable. (3) The block that sets O_CREAT when flags indicate create is suspicious because the comment indicates a create with read-only access "does not make sense" (possible contradictory call paths). (4) The selectable assignment depends on O_NONBLOCK being present in os_perm; whether that bit can ever be set here should be checked (otherwise the assignment may be effectively dead/unreachable-to-be-true).

Why other fragments were NOT selected:
- The individual switch cases (OS_WRITE_ONLY, OS_READ_ONLY, OS_READ_WRITE) are legitimate reachable branches for valid access_mode values and should not be considered unreachable without further evidence that these values can never be passed at runtime.
- The open(local_path, ...) call and the error-handling branch (impl->fd < 0) are normal runtime behavior (open can fail) and therefore reachable.
- The assignments to os_perm for O_TRUNC and the OR with OS_IMPL_REGULAR_FILE_FLAGS are standard flag-building code and are potentially reachable depending on flags/definitions; they are not provably unreachable from the provided code.
- Macro usages (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, OS_DEBUG) and the token/table handling are standard and have no obvious unreachable code in the provided excerpts.

If further proof is available that OS_FileOpen_Impl is never called except via OS_OpenCreate (or that certain flag constants can/cannot be set), the flagged fragments should be revisited to determine whether they are truly unreachable and must be removed or refactored to comply with MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1.
